metadata.title: Land, Labor, and Love: Household Arrangements in Nineteenth Century Eastern Finland-Cultural Heritage or Socio-Economic Structure?
metadata.journal_or_publisher: The History of the Family An International Quarterly

relevance.topic: Household arrangements and socio-economic structures in 19th century Eastern Finland
relevance.relevance: The study is relevant to labor displacement due to technological change as it examines the transition from slash-and-burn agriculture to set field agriculture, which reduced the need for a large workforce and influenced household structures.

design.sample_characteristics: The study focuses on the parish of Virolahti in the province of Viborg, Eastern Finland, during the 19th century.

independent_variables: transition from slash-and-burn agriculture to set field agriculture

dependent_variables.displaced: The transition reduced the need for a large workforce, leading to changes in household structures.

text_fragments: The absence of serfdom and corve 'e labor linked household size and economic needs more directly with ecology and resources.
qualitative_data.narrative_descriptions: The study describes how joint-family households were replaced by stem families as the need for a large workforce diminished with the replacement of slash-and-burn agriculture with set field agriculture.

technological_changes: replacement of slash-and-burn agriculture with set field agriculture
historical_context.economic_conditions: Transition from an economy reliant on slash-and-burn agriculture to one based on set field agriculture and cattle raising.
historical_context.institutional_context: The absence of serfdom and corve 'e labor in Eastern Finland allowed for more direct links between household size and economic needs.

outcomes.main_findings: The study found that economic factors were more influential than cultural factors in determining household structures in Eastern Finland during the 19th century.
outcomes.conclusions: The transition from slash-and-burn to set field agriculture reduced the need for large households, leading to a shift from joint-family to stem-family structures.
